texts.shortText: Due to its morphological similarity to brown algae it is placed within that group, even though it is a red algae. Forms flat, leathery, fan-like lobes resembling a bracket fungus. Lobes attached by a holdfast, but edges free of the substratum. Upper surface dark purplish-red, sometimes tinged with green, but lower surface off-white. Margins of lobes variously incised and surface smooth, but marked with concentric growth rings.
Colonies up to about 120 mm across with individual lobes typically about 80 mm long and 30 mm wide.

Global: Widespread in tropical and temperate waters of Indo-Pacific. Also reported from Angola.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula eastwards to Mozambique.
Common on rocks in deep pools and gullies and to a depth of about 30 m. Especially under overhangs and in caves.
Tertasporangia in groups on raised bumps on dorsal surface.
Fairly unmistakable. Some other species, such as Lobophora variegata and Exallosaurus harveyanus form similar but thinner flat fan-like lobes, but these are brown algae, not red algae.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024. (As Peyssonniella capensis).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 418).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 283 as Peyssonniella capensis).
